text: Still photos of twenty-four principal actors.
Nashville Airport.

TRICYCLE MAN drives into parking lot and parks next to GR old Chevy. TRICYCLE MAM: locks his machine and walks towa coffee shop. GREEN gets out of his car, locks it, starts same direction. NORMAN parks the limo, goes into main bui
NORMAN is attracted to large CONNIE WHITE display.

At the entrance is another "CONNIE WHITE" display and fro jukebox we hear one of her songs. The waitress, SUELEEN, drops a fork, then gets another fr overflowing sink and hands it to her customer, TRICYCLE M There are several people at the counter with him, includi GREEN, who has just walked in. Another man enters, DELBER REESE. SUELEEN waits on all of them. A small black man comes out of the kitchen, carrying a tr or dishes. This is WADE.
(to SUELEEN) You want a ride into town?
You bet.
REESE looks up, checking out SUELEEN, then WADE, then the TRICYCLE MAN, then his breast pocket to see it his wallet checkbook are still there, then he buries himself in his  newspaper.
Got me an audition tonight.
Well, you just remember, if you  can't kick front, kick back, 'cause  at least you're kicking... Ten  minutes, okay?
She nods and talks to the TRICYCLE MAN. REESE keeps sneak looks at her.
I've just been waiting for the  right spot to sing in... I'm so  nervous...
She laughs and starts to rinse the dishes in the sink.

I'm good, though. There ain't but  one Sueleen Gay -- I don't mean to  be conceited, but really it's true.  I've been taking special coaching  lessons from Zeke Willard -- he's  just wonderful. Teaches you how to  phrase; that's really important.  And breathing. Well, you know all  about that. Anyway, I wrote this  song.

She looks down and then begins to half whisper, sing, and all of the gestures for a song she has written as she wip glasses. The jukebox continues to play CONNIE WHITE, and time someone walks by, Sueleen stops. She finally gets th the song and discovers REESE has been watching, too. She away from him to the TRICYCLE MAN, who smiles. Be has fin his meal.
Oh, listen, I really do go on.  Here's your check. Sure has been  nice talking to you.
As she removes her apron, a HAVEN HAMILTON song comes on jukebox, "Keep on a goin'."  The TRICYCLE MAN leaves.

We hear the last chorus or "Keep on a goin'" as sung by H who is recording. He is always dressed in white. In the booth are BUD and L PEARL. Also present are two engineers and a producer. HAV accompanied by a long haired piano player with a white sw HAVEN is not too happy with him.

OPAL enters the booth, carrying a too-large English tape  recorder. HAVEN Stops singing, mad at OPAL'S interruption the piano player. Through the glass we see him pantomimin instructions for her to leave. As she does, HAVEN starts
OPAL wanders to the next studio. BUD follows, apologizing
Sorry. He sees a tape recorder and  gets upset.
She looks at him.
He's my father.
Haven Hamilton is your father? Can  you arrange an interview?
They have entered a different control tooth. In the recor portion, LINNEA and an all-black, male CHOIR sings a gosp OPAL asks BUD who this group is.
BUD returns. HAVEN has just exploded at the piano player starts to leave, yelling at the producer.

Who the hell is playing piano? Get  that hippie out of here... He's got  a tin ear. I asked for Pig, dammit.  I'm moving on 'cause I gotta get to  the airport. When you get my  backups straight, then we'll talk  about cutting this tune here.
He heads for the hallway.
It is jammed with black singers from the CHOIR. HAVEN hat being crushed and moves through the congestion like a whi knight. OPAL moves near.
Excuse me, sir. I'm here putting  together a film. I would like to  ask some questions.
She has to fumble with the bulky tape machine and transfo
Foreigner?
I'm from BBC television.
Where the hell is that?
HAVEN nod a politely and leaves the crowded hallway with PEARL. He spots LINNEA.
Linnea.
How you doing, Haven?
oh, fine. Couldn't be better.
They all say goodbye and HAVEN'S group gets into a new wh
Barbara Jean's plane taxis to a halt.
REESE leaves a tip and exits the coffee shop to greet the Page Missing
TOM spots stews and goes to them
You ladies got room for a spare?
Sure.
L.A. JOAN is left in the dust.
'Bye... nice talking to you.
GREEN sees his niece and walks over.
Joan?
She turns.
Did you see who that was?
Glad to see you. Ester'll be glad,  too.
He is just wonderful.
I'1l get your bag.
GLENN has just deposited a postcard in a mailbox and appr gathering cluster of people. NORMAN and TRICYCLE MAN are Everybody is waiting for BARBARA JEAN to appear. GLENN st close to NORMAN.
Am I late?
Late!  Oh, Jesus!
He runs off.

As NORMAN runs toward passenger loading, we see HAVEN'S j arrive with HAVEN, BUD and PEARL. It parks and all climb REESE and TRIPLETTE approach the 'Barbara Jean' plane. BA is already on the runway, making arrangements. HAVEN'S gr shake hands.
Delbert, how are you?
I'm fine. This here is John  Triplette. Triplette, like you to  meet the Honorary Mayor, Haven  Hamilton.
Good to meet you. (turns to BUD) Bud, have them move the horses.
Pleasure
Where is she?

Still inside the plane posing for  pictures and signing autographs.  She's got a new album cut again.  She'll be down in a minute. But  she'll be late for the Opera if she  doesn't hurry. Bud, get the plane on  the walkie-talkie.
BUD fumbles on his walkie-talkie telephone, but can't see anything.
They don't seem to be answering.  The ambulance boys are here, though.  Barnett always expects them to get  there like a shot. That thing only  goes a hundred fall bore with the  sirens going.
Thank you, Bud.
BUD nods like he has been complimented.

A wave of noise begins from the fans. The band and majore and horses and ropers go into a rendition of one of her h as BARBARA JEAN appears. Everyone is breaking their neck especially GLENN. HAVEN and REESE give her the first roun applause, then go back to talking. TRIPLETTE has never be exposed to anything quite like this before and stands a l awe of the situation. When the twirling and tricking and music stop, BARBARA JE descends the stairs.
Bud, tell them to move the horses.  Promised this strip would be spic  and span.
He smiles and winks.
Listen, we'll go get the car and  come back. This'l1 be going on for  a while.
You bet. She's probably talking to  somebody about their sick child. You  know how she is.
They wave goodbye and head in the direction of the loadin Behind them, the horse people disperse and get into their and horse trailers, preparing to return to Nashville.
BARNETT comes over to REESE, TRIPLETTE, HAVEN, BUD and PE while BARBARA JEAN continues to greet fans.
While the BARBARA JEAN arrival takes place on the runway finds BILL and MARY. NORMAN speaks softly and out of brea trying to pretend he's on time.
Hi.
BILL slaps him on the back and engulfs him.
Hi, Norman.
NORMAN looks relieved. BILL and MARY have been arguing.
Sure is nice to see you all again.  I never thought I'd see you again  after the last time.
Oh, Norman, you worry too much.
MARY takes NORMAN'S hand.
Norman, how are you?
She kisses him and he blushes. BILL and MARY are glad to someone else.
Fine. Just fine.

As they walk to the limo, we see a car with loudspeakers of it and clearly written door signs that read: "Replacem Party" in red, white and blue. REESE and TILIPLETTE are w toward it, shaking hands with several people.
Sure have missed you all, though.  Oh, where's Tom?  Isn't he with you?
Don't worry about old Tom.
TOM and the stews walk to a VW with a sun roof. Nearby REESE and TRIPLETTE get into their Cadillac, behin Replacement Party car. Coming from the loudspeakers a tap recorded VOICE:
Have you thought about your future  and what America needs to examine...
Behind the Replacement Party car is an airport bus with " White" posters on the side. GLENN is one or the passenger cranes his neck to continue watching the runway and BARBA
NORMAN'S limo, with BILL and MARY, follows traffic as the TRICYCLE MAN fires up his machine. WADE'S car with SUELEE joins the procession.

The orange ambulance has moved into the area near the pla there seems to be a great deal at activity. REESE and TRIPLETTE'S car stops, and they rush out and ru HAVEN, who is shouting for people to get the hell out of

Two ambulance ATTENDANTS cut through the crowd. HAVEN, TR and REESE rush near. BARNETT is on his knees over BARBARA who has collapsed. The ATTENDANTS lean over her with ammo They test her reflexes, etc..
How long was she out?
Not too long. But she keeps  passing out.
She comes to and looks at them all.
(oblivious) Just give your manna that vitamin  E. Makes a world of difference.
Here she is again.
She resists the ammonia, looks around and passes out agai
Okay, let's get her to the wagon.

A stretcher is brought in and she is placed under oxygen. climbs into the ambulance with BARBARA JEAN, slamming the DELBERT and TRIPLETTE. HAVEN stands there, yelling at peo DELBERT and TRIPLETTE rush back to their car as the ambul speeds off, siren wailing.
leads the procession.
Eater's been asking for you.
L.A. JOAN is trying to find a station she likes on her tr radio.
Uh huh.
She's been in the hospital two  weeks yesterday.
L.A. JOAN can't find anything she likes.
You know anything about the  stations here?
(hasn't heard)  It's hard to say. Doctors thought  she'd come home a week ago. All it  was was appendix.
All they got is advertisements.  Just like L.A.
Did an exploratory and according to  them, she needed an overhaul.
He chuckles at his prepared joke.
Well, I could use one, especially  if I'm pregnant.
What did you say?
I said, maybe I'll change my name  again.
I see... Well, those doctors are  real miracle workers.
But not unless Nashville really  inspires me.
Maybe you can look after me a  little.
That Tom sure is cute.
speeding by each vehicle. BARBARA JEAN and BARNETT are al
being very piggish in its driving habits.

We had these two city boys come in  last week. One or them said his  Ford truck had cut off his foot.  The other one said that wasn't true.  Then the first said he looked just  like Eddie Black when he said  that...
Bud, would you be sure to get the  oil changed?
Ya... where do you want me to take  it?
Do you remember Eddie Black? He had  those blue eyes.
Where you always take it. There's  nothing special about this time.
And they started pounding on each  other. But the one without the foot  was strongest.
Bud, you're going to have to show  up at the hospital tar me I gotta  get back to that session.
Okay. Anything you want me to say?
Say I had to get back to the  session. ~ God -- All school did  for you, you can put in a thimble.
The cops came through and broke it  up. I finally just had to call Chet  and say, 'Chet, get over here. There  are two old bays here breaking up  the furniture...'
SUELEEN in doing some vocal exercising. WADE listens for
Is that what you're going to sing?
She laughs.

No -- That's exercises. My coach  says you have to do exercise because  the vocal chords are muscle and need  to be stretched. Every time you  stretch them, the middle part sets  stronger. That's the place where I  sing.
You think I got any kind of a  voice?
He breaks into a scale.
You sure do it loud.
Is that good?
It's not bad.
You think I should take lessons?
If you're serious. Being serious  is real important.
You serious?
Wade -- I've been working toward  this audition for years.
Well, honey, I sure hope it comes  your way then.
You think it will?
Sure thing.
I just knew that was you when you  got on.
You did, huh?
Ya - I even recognized them.
How long have you been together?
(laughing) Too long.
Is your rather really an actor?
(laughing) All his life.
Really?
Me, too.
They all laugh. STEW #4 has been driving over-cautiously of the cargo. TOM leans over and kisses her ear.
You having any fun?
She shrieks and practically drives off the road. They all
That's the most important thing -- to have -- fun
How long are you going to be here?
Long enough to have fun.
They laugh.
What do you think of him?
Hal? Well, Hal and I have been  friends for a long time.
You go to school together?
No, we never did that
Oh --
We're connected by a relative. One  time, one of his aunts married one  of my uncles. That was a long time  ago, though. How'd you come to work  for him?
Well, I really think he's got a  chance.
You do?
Oh yea -- There has never been a  better time for something new.
He ain't really new.
He is to a lot of people.
He was a good Judge, but that was a  long time ago.
You know, I'll bet you he makes it  with a majority.
Where are you from?
Southern California.
You always live there?
Spent time in Arizona. Why?
Well, I admire your optimism, and I  just wondered if it was regional.  You ever see any movie stars?
I know a couple.
No kidding -- Wait till I tell  Linnea. Who?
Ah... Peter Finch.
Who?
Peter Finch -- he's English.
I never heard of him. Name  somebody else.
Ryan O'Neal.
You really do?  ~ God -- How come  you know them?
Oh, you meet them at parties and  stuff.
I'll be damned. Boy, if you could  get Ryan to say something about Hal  Phillip Walker, wouldn't that be  something?
Well -- maybe. Let's see what  happens here.
I'll be dammed.
GLENN is at the window. "Connie White" ads are present.
Part of normal traffic. It belongs to TOMMY BROWN, who lo with four very black associates, playing serious poker.
Joining the procession from an auxiliary route. With her OPAL, who interviews LINNEA.
Have your children been deaf since  birth?
Yes -- yes, they have. It was a  real shock at first, especially  since my daddy's a preacher, but  Delbert and I have been blessed by  their being here.
When did you start singing?
When I was little, in church.
Isn't it unusual for you to be  working with a black choir?
Yes, it is --
Well, can you tell me why?
It just is.
(not getting the  answer she wants) How long have you been with them?
About three years.
And before?
Just my church and my boys. We all  had to go to school and learn hand  talking. I just thank the Lord they  can see.
Do you ever do any writing?
No, I don't.
Are you a close friend of Haven's?
No, mostly his wife's. She's in  Paris, France, right now. My  husband Delbert is real friendly  with him. Delbert's in law. Does  work for him.
Do you like him?
He's a member of our congregation.
KENNY is caught up in the crowd entering Nashville.
You got the money?
Right here.
Well, don't lose it. Last time I  gave you twenty-five dollars, you  lost it.
Well, that just happened that time.
Well, it better not happen again.
ALBUQUERQUE turns and looks out the window. They ride in  resentful silence.
You lost twenty-five dollars once  before that, too, near Christmas  time -- I remember that real well  now. December 9th, to be exact.
You got a real good memory, Star.
I remember when I just saw you.  Skinny Winnifred. Jesus, you were  skinny.
(ignoring him) What do you have to buy?
Feed, mostly. Thought we'd get  something for the kids.
Okay by me - I'd sure like to see  that Opryland.
What?
Grand Old Opera --
I hate that music.
I know that, Star.

Near a bridge, a huge diesel truck almost collides with t Replacement car, which has just made a greedy move. To avoid collision, the diesel jackknifes, blocking all t behind it, except for one narrow lane.
MARY sits erect.
Oh, my God!
BILL climbs out.
Norman, just sit there and don't  puke.
He runs toward the truck. At this point, the TRICYCLE MAN appears through all the cars.
The TRICYCLE MAN works his way through traffic. STAR has from his truck and goes to help. ALBUQUESQUE takes advant runs off.
It overheats and explodes. KENNY gets out, carrying his v case and starts to walk. ALBUQUERQUE spots him and steps
Hey, mind if I walk with ya?
She looks at his violin case.
You a musician?
No.
Do you have people in Nashville?
No -- Just coming to Nashville,  that's all.
BARNETT is in a rage. The ATTENDANTS administer oxygen to
I don't care. I pay you people  twenty-five bucks an hour and keep  you working steady. Now either go on  or turn around. But move.
The ambulance passes all the vehicles, including the hors As he passes NORMAN'S limo:
Don't worry, Norman. There's no  blood. Nobody's hurt.
She climbs out of the car and moves to the freeway rail a for some workmen below to call the police.
The driver is hurt badly. TRICYCLE MAN and STAR are there looks up, relieved an ambulance is coming. His face drops ambulance speeds past and toward the city.
ALBUQUERQUE is walking with KENNY. She sees STAR returnin his truck. She ducks into the ivy.
Hurt my foot...
STAR approaches his truck, sees ALBUQUERQUE is gone and s KSNNY.
Have you seen a woman about so  high?
No.
She had on high heels?
No.
Need a ride?
KENNY nods "yes" and climbs in the pickup.
People are helping the injured driver. TRICYCLE MAN climb his machine and leaves, heading toward Nashville.
BARBARA JEAN is in bed. A DOCTOR is there, along with a c publicity people and well-wishers, including: TRIPLETTE, BUD. BARNETT hovers over BARBARA JEAN. The atmosphere is  stifling.
Barbara, I'd like to talk to you  and Barnett alone.
Anything you say.
He turns to the visitors.
Doctor says you'll have to go on  out now
There are tones of disappointment, most of them are very in their own conversations. TRIPLETTE walks toward the be can't really get close enough. He finally captures BARNET the people start to leave.
Excuse me, Barnett, how's she  doing?
BARNETT turns and studies him for a moment as though he r who he is. He doesn't.

I'm sorry. I feel as if I know you.  I'm John Triplette... a friend of  Del Reese... I was at the airport.  I just wanted to introduce myself.  I'm a great fan of hers. If there's  anything you need, just give me a  call. I'm at the Sheraton South.
She's going to rest now.
Okay, I just wanted to see if I  could help out at all.
The crowd is almost out of the room now. We see GLENN the steps into the hallway.
I appreciate your concern, but she  has to rest, so you can go on home.
Oh, sure.
He stands there too long.
What do you really want?
Not a thing, Barnett, really. I  need a little information. But, ah,  it can wait.
You bet.
Okay. Thanks.
BARNETT says "you bet" again and closes the door after TR BARNETT returns to the bed with BARBARA JEAN and the DOCT
Well, it's exhaustion, pure and  simple, and you're going to have to  take a rest or you're going to be in  big trouble.
She has to be at the opera tomorrow  night and then she can go home.
She's not going anywhere, Barnett.  This is precisely what I'm talking  about. She is collapsing. She  cannot go on without a rest or she  will have to stop altogether for a  long time.

Well, I have to go:  It's too late  to be replaced, and, besides, I just  can't do that. Those people get  disappointed. They've come in from  all over, you know, and this Miss  Foxy who's been writing to me for  years is going to be there from  Michigan.

You cannot leave this bed until I  say so. The two of you have to  understand that. Barnett, you've  got to stop this dovetailing and  give her some rest. You don't need  to make that much more money.
It's not the money. The friends  and neighbors love her and they want  to see her. We got a debt to the  public.
Well, they are not going to see her  tomorrow night, and I suggest you  get on the phone and make the  necessary arrangements.

A few of the people still remain, among them GLENN, who h finished another postcard. Near BARBARA JEANS' hospital r MRS. GREEN'S. GREEN is visiting her now and LA. JOAN wait the hall, smoking a cigarette. BUD is talking with a few L.A. JOAN brings out a new cigarette and asks GLENN for a He doesn't have one, so she moves to BUD. She scares him, lights her fresh cigarette anyway. She asks him for a rid they leave together as GREEN comes out. GREEN begins to l L.A. JOAN.
TRICYCLE MAN parks in front. He enters.
SUELEEN is auditioning. The TRICYCLE MAN goes to the bar listens. He is one of the few people who do. SUELEEN dire her performance to him. Also at the bar is TOM, being interviewed by OPAL.
We just got a gold record.
Do they have a show to give it to  you?
No  Hell, some secretary in New  York just hands it to you. Only  this one kept dropping it out of the  box.
Did it break?
Dent it a little. Boy -- just she  couldn1t even find it. She had a  hamburger on her desk that looked  three weeks old.
How long have you been together?
Probably a little too long.
Do you study at all?
Depends on what I'm studying.
STAR is down at the end, drinking alone and looking for  ALBUQUERQUE. The phone rings and the MANAGER answers it.
Establish the REESES' relationship with their children. D speaks to TRIPLETTE
When do you need her?
Monday night.
You want her to sing, too?
Sueleen has finished her song and eavesdrops blatantly.
I can do benefits
(into phone) How much?
Twenty dollars for her and ten for  you.
The MANAGER keeps looking at SUELEEN
Well, do you want a blonde?
How does she look?
You know... blonde.
Okay, I'll get you your money.
Both hang up the telephones.
The MANAGER carefully looks at SUELEEM.
I can only give you fifty a week  here and ten bucks for the benefit.
Money's no object.
She kisses his cheek. He hates it. He writes on a piece o paper.
You go here Monday night and be  there at eight sharp and look flashy  you know what I mean?
She nods "yes" and takes the paper.
Are you sure you know what you're  doing?
Hundreds of times.
Well, there's a couple of girls in  Printers Alley if you got any  questions. I know I've seen that G- string stuff for sale someplace  around.
Don't you worry about Sueleen Gay.
She isn't convincing.
That's for sure. At the airport -  that's where it was. At the  airport, there in one of those gift  shops... Anyway, you better take a  break.
Thanks. You are just a wonderful  person.
ALBUQUERQUE enters. STAR sees her and chases her outside.
STAR hits the pavement, but there is no sign or ALBUQUERQ stands there as BUD and L.A. JOAN enter.
BUD and L.A. JOAN go to the bar as SUELEEN sings another TOM has moved away from OPAL to the telephone.
DELBERT, TRIPLETTE, LINNEA and the kids are eating. The p rings. LINNEA answers it.
Hello.
Linnea?
Yes. Who's this?
I'm here.
Who is this?
Tom. You remember?
(concealing her  laughter) I'm not sure. Where?
Remember, about a month ago, your  church choir cut a record?
Yes.
Well, I met you that afternoon in  the control room and we...
Oh, Tom, of course. What are you  doing in Nashville?
Cutting a record. Pauses.
I'd really like to see you.
Or course. You should come over to  the house. The boys would love to  meet you.
(laughs) That's not quite what I had in  mind.
She tries not to hear what he's saying.
Well...How have you been?
Well, they removed my heart last  week, but I'm doing fine except my  nose fell off. Looks a little  funny.
She laughs.
Look, I find you attractive and I  want to see you, so I'll call you  when I get to my place.
He hangs up the phone. LINNEA looks at the dinner table a DELBERT and the kids.
TOM moves back to the bar and OPAL. L.A. JOAN has found t TRICYCLE MAN more interesting than BUD and slides close t BUD takes the opportunity to sneak out.

NORMAN is on stage doing his routine, a series of imitati jokes, with help from Bluegrass pickers, who introduce hi audience. BILL and MARY are in the audience, watching NOR At another table sit BARNETT, TOMMY BROWN, PEARL, HAVEN  negotiating a deal and watching NORMAN as a potential war act. They think he stinks

KENNY enters with his violin case and sits. Near the back is drunk, leaning against the wall. ALBUQUERQUE enters fr back door. She hangs around the kitchen, stealing food. W notices her and starts to talk to her.
Hey, what are you doing?
ALBUQUERQUE pretends she's fixing her purse.
Just fixing this strap here

I know what you're doing. I've  done it too long not to know. But if  you're going to hunt down food, get  enough so you won't have to do it  again right away. Peanut butter's  good. Man can last a long time on  peanut butter.
ALBURQUERQUE can't find any, so she grabs whatever she ca will fit into her purse.
NORMAN caters his material to TOMMY BROWN, hoping to get
(quite drunk and  yelling) Tommy Brown, you are the whitest  nigger I have ever seen.
TOMMY turns in his chair and looks at WADE. BARNETT leans TOMMY.
Let's go --
I don't think Norman's done yet.
We've heard enough. Come on.
Hell, you're whiter than that old  boy up there.
TOMMY and BARNETT leave.
Where the hell are you going, Oreo  cookie?

The Bluegrass players pick up the tempo by playing music. tries to calm WADE down, but WADE belts him. NORMAN sings National Anthem. PEARL gets mad and tosses WADE out the b door. ALBUQUERQUE goes after WADE to soothe him. BILL, MA NORMAN leave together out the front. ALBUQUERQUE watches alley.
MARY mothers NORMAN. BILL, MARY and NORMAN enter the limo leaving KENNY behind. STAR drives up. He recognizes KENNY the freeway
Hey, there - You seen my Winifred?
No.
You got a place to stay?
No. Probably stay at a motel  tonight.
(looking at  violin case) You in music?
No.
Get in.
KENNY climbs in.
TRICYCLE MAN drives L.A. JOAN to the hospital. She climbs his machine.
I hope he's still here. I don't  know where he lives.
GREEN comes out of the hospital and walks over. He is hur
You should have stayed. Ester's  been wanting to see you.
They walk off to GREEN'S car. TRICYCLE MAN drives oft.
GLENN is in the middle of the rose garden gathering a bou flowers. When he finishes, he enters the building.
GLENN walks past the desk, holding the bouquet so no one it. He enters the elevator.

in the most despicable kind of condition. ALBUQUERQUE wad through the waste, uses the John, then discovers it won't She goes to wash her hands but there is only a trickle. S takes some Kleenex from her purse and dries her face and exiting the bathroom with the key still in the door.

GLENN eases out of the chair where he has been sitting al He has been writing a letter and puts it near the glass o flowers. He looks at BARBARA JEAN for the last time, puts chair back, and leaves, bumping into an entering NURSE.
Who are you?
GLENN is too scared to say anything and takes off down th The NURSE checks BARBARA JEAN and lets it go at that.
TOM is in bed with OPAL. He gets up and goes to the windo see the TRICYCLE MAN'S machine parked outside.
Come on back to bed.
Yeah, you bet. You're really  terrific. You know what I mean?
Come on.
Just a minute.
He goes to his Jacket and pulls out a phone number, then to dial.
Hello.
Hiya. Listen, is Linnea there?
There is a long pause.
Hello.
Hi.
Another long pause.
Listen, 1'm sorry I didn't call a  little sooner. I sorta got tied up.  Listen...
OPAL is getting dressed and gathering her things.
Who is thin?
Who is this?  It's Tom.
I don't know who you are.
What do you mean?  You said you  wanted to see me.
OPAL is almost ready to leave. She sees the tricycle park outside. LINNEA has hung up on TOM and he dials again.
What the hell is going on?
What is this?
I would like to talk to...
